Fig. 1 Schematic of a 2-phase FDO scheme. Phase 1 is the reaction phase, phase 2 is the regeneration phase. The reaction temperature was 330 °C. The duty cycle was fixed at 50%. 0.65 g catalyst was mixed with 1 g SiO2. Steady-state ACN traces (SSO) are shown in gray for comparison. (b) ACN production and (c) ACN yield are also shown for each cycle period in comparison with SSO. The outlet stream of the reactor was diluted 6 times with N2 to meet FTIR flowrate requirements. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) ACN concentration as a function of time while cycling between C3H6:NH3:O2 = 1500:1500:3000 ppm and 3000 ppm O2, with different duty cycles (50–90%) for a fixed cycle period of 10 min as well as the ACN produced with a constant inlet mixture (SSO) of C3H6:NH3:O2 = 1500:1500:3000 ppm, T = 330 ºC. (b) ACN production and (c) ACN yield with FDO with different duty cycles in comparison with SSO. (b) ACN production and (c) ACN yield in FDO with different O2 concentrations in O2 regeneration phase for fixed cycle period of 10 min and duty cycle of 90%, compared to that of SSO with C3H6:NH3:O2 = 1500:1500:3000 ppm. The SSO ACN traces at each temperature are also displayed. (c) ACN production and (d) ACN yield using FDO and SSO vs. temperature. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Description of the C3H6 +NH3 reducing cycles used in evaluating the lattice oxygen available in the industrial BMO catalyst. C3H6:NH3 = 1500:1500 ppm for 10 min, N2 for 10 min. The total flowrate was 50 sccm and the experiment was done at 330 °C. (b) Lattice oxygen consumed during the reducing cycles was calculated by considering CO, CO2, ACO and H2O formed. (c) ACN concentrations during FDO after a different number of reducing cycles at 330 ºC. FDO conditions are the same as those of Fig. 2 with a 20 min cycle period. SSO results from the same sample are also shown. (d) ACN moles formed, (e) ACN yield and (f) C3H6 conversion and product selectivity during the first FDO cycle indicated by the arrow in (c). ACA = acetaldehyde, COx = CO+CO2. Note, this is a different sample than that used in Figs. 2–5 and 7. Propene ammoxidation to acrylonitrile (ACN) over bismuth molybdate-based catalysts has been commercialized for more than 60 years. To meet forecasted growth, there is an opportunity for smaller-scale, decentralized ACN production. Forced dynamic operation (FDO), here referring to step changes in reactant inlet concentrations, has been used in low-volume production applications and has shown advantages in partial oxidation reactions. As a proof-of-concept study to evaluate FDO for acrylonitrile production, we applied periodic changes in inlet gas concentrations that varied between one phase containing all reactants and another that just contained O2, over an industrial bismuth molybdate-based catalyst. We varied the cycle period, duty cycle, and O2 concentration in the second phase and show that improved acrylonitrile yields can be obtained compared with those of steady-state operation under certain conditions. A correlation between lattice oxygen availability and FDO performance was observed. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Propene ammoxidation Forced dynamic operation Acrylonitrile Bismuth molybdate Lattice oxygen Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Forced dynamic operation (FDO) is a technique that involves periodically changing reactor or reaction conditions [1,2]. The goals of FDO usually include improving selectivity and yield to the desired product. FDO can be realized through composition forcing, or feed concentration modulation. The variables in this case are usually the cycle period and duty cycle, which is the duration of one phase of the cycle relative to the total cycle period. FDO has been employed in a variety of reactions, for example, NH3 synthesis [3,4] and partial oxidation of hydrocarbons, such as methane to syngas [5,6] and ethylene to ethylene oxide [7,8]. Using NH3 synthesis as the first example, the NH3 synthesis reaction can be inhibited by excess H2, where the adsorbed H covers the active sites so the dissociation of N2 is impeded[9,10]. Using FDO to control the exposure of H2 to reduce inhibition, Silveston and coauthors showed a 30% rate improvement using FDO over a broad range of cycling conditions [3]. As a second example, partial oxidation of hydrocarbons reactions can occur through lattice oxygen rather than molecular oxygen. In such cases the catalyst serves as an oxygen carrier [2]. FDO can split the reaction into two steps: reduction by hydrocarbon and re-oxidation by gaseous O2, helping to avoid total oxidation. As one example, Fathi and coworkers showed that methane oxidation to syngas via FDO was highly selective with a cerium oxide catalyst [6]. Ammoxidation of propene to acrylonitrile (ACN) is also a partial oxidation reaction. It was developed by SOHIO (Standard Oil of Ohio) in the 1950s using bismuth molybdate-based catalysts in the selective oxidation of propene and ammonia to produce acrylonitrile [11–18]: C 3 H 6 + N H 3 + 1.5 O 2 → C H 2 = CHCN + 3 H 2 O ∆ H 298 K = − 515 kJ / mol ACN is mainly used in the production of polymers such as polyacrylonitrile (PAN, a main component of acrylic fiber and used in the manufacture of carbon fiber), acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS) or in the synthesis of other value-added chemicals such as adiponitrile and acrylamide [19]. As a large volume commodity chemical, ACN was produced at a rate of ∼7 million metric tons per year worldwide in 2018 [20]. The capital investment in infrastructure for a new plant is a major hurdle to increasing ACN production capacity. Large-scale plants (typically 250 to 400 kt/a), however, may not be ideal considering historical variability in market demand. Furthermore, production systems having readily scalable manufacturing capacities can mitigate this capital cost risk with, for example, decentralized, small-scale production plants [21] in niche, high value end-use applications such as carbon fiber production [22,23]. Another such example is low-volume syngas or biofuel production using geographically distributed feedstock such as natural gas from off-shore fields or biomass from rural farms, which minimizes transportation cost compared with centralized production [24,25]. Smaller-scale reactors for such applications could benefit from FDO as a potential approach that fits smaller reactor units. FDO in propene ammoxidation has its inception in the propene oxidation to acrolein (ACO) reaction, before the SOHIO process was developed[11]. Realizing the partial oxidation of propene to ACO could be divided into two cycles, where first propene reacts with lattice oxygen from the metal oxide catalyst, then the reduced catalyst is reoxidized by gaseous oxygen, in 1952 the SOHIO engineers proposed using two separate reactors, one for each half reaction [26]. This redox catalysis concept was later independently developed in a more rigorous manner through describing the reaction as a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism in 1954 [27]. Grasselli et al. later further developed this Mars-van Krevelen mechanism path for propene ammoxidation, where NH3 and C3H6 sequentially react with lattice oxygen of the catalyst to form ACN and water first, then the reduced catalyst is reoxidized by dioxygen to its original state[11]. However, this two-reactor concept never came to commercialization because it required circulation of large amounts of solid catalysts [11]. Nonetheless, for smaller-scale production, alternating feed gas composition or feed modulation is a much easier process than circulating the catalyst. Silveston and coworkers studied FDO for propene partial oxidation to ACO, applying a propene lean/rich cycling scheme with an antimony-tin mixed oxide catalyst. One notable finding was that acrolein yield was enhanced with decreasing modulation amplitude [28]. Magagula and van Steen explored the use of FDO in propene ammoxidation over an iron antimony oxide catalyst by alternating feed gases between reduction (propene, ammonia, and air) and reoxidation (ammonia and air) phases [29]. It was revealed that the selectivity and yield to ACN increase almost 2-fold compared with those obtained before the reoxidation phase, in other words when the cycles switched from the reoxidation to reduction phase, however these increases were short-lived in that they only lasted for several minutes. The authors concluded that the periodic reoxidation phase brought the Fe-Sn-O catalyst surface back to a higher oxidation state so that the ACN formation rate was temporarily maintained at high levels. Similar FDO strategies also resulted in an increase in selectivity and productivity in partial oxidation of hydrocarbons to maleic anhydride (MA) over vanadia-based catalysts, where the feed alternated between a butane plus oxygen phase and an oxygen-containing, butane absent phase. One phenomenon of note is that when the oxygen phase was replaced by the butane-containing phase, a transient overshoot in MA production was observed, i.e. MA formed initially rose with the transition between phases and then fell to a lower level [30,31]. Li et al. ascribed this extra MA formation to the lattice oxygen in the near surface layer of the catalysts and postulated that it was the consumption of this surface oxygen species that caused the transient increase in MA formation [31]. These early investigations into selective oxidation utilizing FDO show promise and pointed to lattice oxygen being an active part of the reaction. Herein, we investigated propene ammoxidation to acrylonitrile via FDO over an industrial multicomponent-promoted bismuth molybdate-based catalyst by varying cycle period, duty cycle, O2 input and reactor temperature. The FDO time-averaged ACN production rates are compared with those of steady-state operation. We tentatively probed the relationship between catalytic performance (ACN production and yield) and lattice oxygen availability and found a correlation. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Materials A powdered form, silica-supported, industrial, bismuth molybdate-based catalyst was provided by INEOS Nitriles USA LLC. Per agreement with INEOS Nitriles, chemical analysis of this industrial catalyst was not allowed. However, references regarding the composition of commercialized acrylonitrile catalysts in recent literature can be found in these references [20,32–38]. INEOS Nitriles provided this description for reference - notebook number 20635–9-1. 2.2 Catalytic performance The reactor set-up is illustrated in Fig. S1, where the gas delivery system is comprised of two separate lines. The gas mixture in each line corresponds to a “phase” in the 2-phase FDO scheme. C3H6, NH3, O2 and N2 flowrates were controlled by MKS mass flow controllers. The reactor is equipped with Swagelok 4-way valves automated by Hanbay Inc. actuators and a bypass line. The upstream 4-way valve controls which gas mixture goes into the reactor. NH3, HCN, NO, NO2, N2O, H2O, CO, CO2, C3H6, acetaldehyde (ACA), acrolein (ACO) and acrylonitrile (ACN) concentrations were measured using an MKS2030 FTIR gas analyzer. The reactor was a quartz tube with an 11 mm internal diameter. The quartz tube resided in a Thermo Scientific Lindberg Blue M tube furnace, set horizontally. The catalyst was pelletized and sieved to 60–40 mesh (250–425 µm) pellets, mixed with nitric acid washed SiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich) of the same size and placed between two quartz wool pads into the quartz tube. Two K-type thermocouples purchased from Omega were placed at the end of the two quartz wool pads to measure the temperature upstream and downstream of the catalyst. The temperature range investigated was 310 to 380 °C. Note, the catalyst temperature was typically 1–2 °C below the furnace set point temperature. The temperatures plotted and listed are those of the inlet thermocouple. The carbon balance, C3H6 conversion, NH3 conversion, ACN selectivity and ACN yield were calculated as follows (these definitions apply to the whole FDO cycle, not just phase 1): Carbon balance ( % ) = ∑ a i n i + 3 × moles of C 3 H 6 out 3 × moles of C 3 H 6 in × 100 where a i is the carbon number of product i, n i is the moles of product i; C 3 H 6 Conversion ( % ) = moles of C 3 H 6 in − moles of C 3 H 6 out moles of C 3 H 6 in × 100 N H 3 Conversion ( % ) = moles of NH 3 in − moles of NH 3 out moles of NH 3 in × 100 ACN selectivity ( % ) = 3 × moles of ACN ∑ a i n i × 100 ACN yield ( % ) = C 3 H 6 Conversion × ACN selectivity × 100 The catalyst was pretreated for 1 h in a flowrate of 100 sccm of 10% O2/N2 at 500 °C before reaction tests. This pretreatment should allow for reoxidation of the sample after ammoxidation experiments as well as removal of any C that might have deposited during the experiments. With a constant inlet gas mixture, the inlet gas conditions were C3H6:NH3:O2 = 1500:1500:3000 ppm, balanced in N2, with a total flowrate of 50 sccm. Note, these concentrations are lower than those that would be used in commercial practice. However, this study is a proof-of-concept regarding FDO and not meant to describe a new commercial process. The contact time with this flow and catalyst volume was 2.3 s. Due to the constraints of the FTIR analyzer cell volume, we found that the flow rate to the analyzer needed to be maintained at > 200 sccm. We therefore diluted the reactor effluent with an additional 250 sccm N2 flow, for a total flowrate to the analyzer of 300 sccm. Thus, the gas concentrations reflected in the figures are diluted 6 times – the real concentrations are those shown, multiplied by 6. In FDO, there are 2 phases, phase 1 corresponds to the inlet gas conditions as described above for the constant inlet gas mixture, C3H6:NH3:O2 = 1500:1500:3000 ppm, balanced in N2. In the second phase, the inlet gas concentrations were varied, and this is called phase 2 below. In the most common FDO cycling scheme we used, the inlet gas mixture in phase 2 contains only O2 diluted in N2, and we termed this specific scenario the regeneration (i.e., catalyst reoxidation) phase, shown in Fig. 1. The pressure drop across the catalyst was calculated and found to be negligible. Diffusion limitation criteria were also calculated and shown in the SI, and their effects on the reaction can be ignored. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of cycle period We examined FDO with the inlet gas conditions listed in Table 1. In this normal feed/O2 regeneration FDO scheme, the cycle starts with phase 1 containing all reactant gases: C3H6, NH3 and O2, followed by phase 2 with O2 in N2 only (no C3H6 and NH3). We performed these experiments at 330 °C, chosen such that the ACN yield is significant, and the N-conversion has not reached 100% (Fig. S2). In the first set of FDO experiments, the impact of cycle period was assessed. The cycle period was varied from 4 to 20 min, with a fixed duty cycle of 50%. The reactor outlet ACN concentration as a function of time is shown in Fig. 2a. All FDO experiments show an overshoot in ACN concentration with the transition between phase 2 to phase 1. As an example, for the 20 min cycle period, the ACN concentration rose rapidly to a value above 50 ppm, then slowly fell to a lower intensity, below 50 ppm, before reaching a steady-state concentration, thereby creating what we call a “spike” feature. And this ACN concentration exceeded that of the constant inlet gas mixture experiment shown, labelled as SSO – steady state operation. We observed the same ACN production transient with SSO as with FDO in the first few minutes, suggesting that the catalyst starts out in a more active state. One possible explanation for the decrease in conversion to ACN is carbon deposition. We therefore evaluated the carbon balance during SSO, and it was 95%, indicating that coking is not likely the cause of the slow fall in ACN productivity. The catalytic performance in phase 1 is always regenerated after phase 2, which is why we labelled it the O2 regeneration phase. Similar overshoot phenomena in FDO are not uncommon, with examples in transient response studies of ammoxidation of propene and propane [39], also in the selective oxidation of hydrocarbons to maleic anhydride as mentioned earlier [30,31,40], or in propane oxidative dehydrogenation to propene [41–43]. The “spikes” of desired product maleic anhydride or propene occurred with a step-change from an oxygen-rich phase to hydrocarbon-rich phase. These overshoot responses were believed to be related to the regeneration of surface active sites [44]. Integrated ACN production (µmol/h) is shown in Fig. 2b and was calculated based on ACN produced for the first 80 min in all experiments. With increasing cycle period, the ACN production decreases, which can be explained by the longer cycle periods having a lower proportion of ACN spikes. Integrated ACN production for the FDO experiments is less than that obtained with SSO, which is understandable since the duty cycle is only 50%, such that half of the time no ACN is produced due to a lack of reactants. On the other hand, if we are comparing ACN yield (propene conversion*ACN selectivity), FDO shows advantage (∼23%) over SSO (20%) as displayed in Fig. 2c. Note, an error analysis suggests this difference is significant, with the highest error noted in SSO experiments being 0.8% and in FDO 4x less. This increase in ACN yield was caused mainly by the increase in C3H6 conversion, with the contribution from ACN selectivity limited (see Fig S3). The selectivity to side products, ACO, carbon oxides (CO and CO2), acetaldehyde and HCN, were not significantly affected with the current FDO conditions. Note, in analyzing the temperatures measured, it was found that any fluctuations in upstream and downstream temperatures of the catalyst bed were not correlated to periodic switching of the phases. And similar fluctuations were also seen during SSO. These fluctuations are simply related to the furnace T control. Maximum temperature variation during any experiment was 2 ºC. 3.2 Effect of duty cycle The impact of increasing the FDO duty cycle from 50 to 90% on ACN production was also investigated. With a cycle period of 10 min, the results are shown in Fig. 3. With the increased duty cycle, the ACN spike intensity decreased (Fig. 3a). Our hypothesis is that the shorter O2 regeneration phase caused the decrease via less regeneration of the active oxygen species. Nonetheless, the overall trend is ACN production increased with duty cycle (Fig. 3b). ACN production did not increase with the final increase to 90% duty cycle (Fig. 3b), indicating that decreasing the O2 regeneration time past a certain point no longer increased ACN production. 4 min and 20 min FDO cycle periods show similar trends with increased duty cycle (Fig S4), but still in no case did the FDO performance exceed that of SSO. The ACN yield with FDO decreased from 23 to 19%, with the increase of duty cycle from 50 to 90%. With 90% duty cycle, ACN yield dropped below that of SSO, Fig. 3c. The decrease in ACN yield was mainly due to the decrease in C3H6 conversion. Selectivity towards ACN even showed a small increase with duty cycle (Fig S5). It appears that the activity was primarily impacted by the extent of catalyst reoxidation. 3.3 Effect of O2 concentration in the regeneration phase As stated above, we hypothesized that the ACN production was limited by the O2 regeneration phase time. If true, fixing the duty cycle while increasing the O2 concentration in the regeneration phase should enhance ACN production. Reactor outlet ACN concentrations and production during FDO with varying O2 concentration in the regeneration phase, with a fixed cycle period of 10 min and a duty cycle of 90% are shown in Fig. 4. The O2 concentration was increased from 0.3 to 10%. ACN production increases with a rise in O2 concentration in the regeneration phase, and at 0.6% O2 the performance exceeds that of SSO. The extent of enhancement of ACN production is more limited with increasing O2 concentration, with the ACN production increase between 1.2% and 10% O2 negligible. We also fixed the total O2 dose to 1.2%* 1 min, or ∼27 μmol O2, and varied the O2 regeneration time from 1 min to 0.25 min, and the results are similar (Fig S6). The ACN yield using FDO also increases with O2 concentration in the regeneration phase, at 0.6% O2 it exceeds that of SSO. As shown in Fig. 4c, the yield improvement is not pronounced beyond O2 = 1.2%. Again, the C3H6 conversion had the greater impact on ACN yield (Fig. S7). To better understand how the catalyst utilizes the gaseous oxygen in the regeneration phase, i.e., to further our understanding of how the catalyst works via the Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism, an analysis on how increasing the O2 in the regeneration phase vs. the improvement in ACN production is described in Table S1. The results quantitatively show that the portion of the added oxygen beyond the 0.3% in the regeneration phase that contributes to the additional ACN production, decreases with increasing O content. This of course makes sense since the O added is well beyond that needed for the reaction stoichiometry. But it does show that there is contribution, it is just not 1:1. We also investigated the influence of O2 concentration in SSO at 330 °C, shown in Fig. S8. The ACN production and ACN yield generally increased with O2 concentration. With O2 = 0.6 to 0.9%, the performance in SSO is comparable to those of FDO with O2 concentration 0.6 to 0.9% in the regeneration phase, the difference is that with FDO 90% of the time O2 concentration is at 0.3%, it only requires high O2 concentration 10% of the time. Overall, the activity increased with the extent of catalyst reoxidation and our observations show that periodically injecting a certain amount of O2 into the reactor after exposure to the ammoxidation reaction conditions can transiently enhance FDO performance, and under certain conditions surpass that of SSO. 3.4 Effect of temperature We investigated the impact of temperature on FDO performance in the range of 310–380 °C with the optimal FDO scheme obtained in the previous section, with an O2 concentration = 1.2% in the regeneration phase, and the results are shown in Fig. 5. At 310 °C, FDO showed low ACN productivity. The ACN concentrations during the first phase of the cycle in FDO and that of SSO overlapped (Fig. 5a). ACN concentrations during the first phase of the FDO cycle began to show higher values than SSO at 330 °C, where, as was previously shown, there were ACN spikes following the O2 regeneration phase. Here, we define the area under the ACN overshoot in FDO and above the SSO as the “spike region” (Fig S9a) and quantify the spike area and show its change with temperature in Fig S9b. The integral areas under the spike region became smaller when the temperature was increased to 360 and 380 °C (Fig. 5b). ACN productions during FDO at these two higher temperatures did not surpass that of SSO (Fig. 5c), and this trend was also observed via the comparison of percentage of spike region as part of the total ACN production (Spike/Total ACN) shown in Fig S9b, where at 330 °C the spike% was ∼15% whilst at 360 or 380 °C it was less than or equal to 5%. We hypothesize that this spike% value suggests that the labile lattice oxygen in the surface of the catalyst (regenerated from gaseous O2) at 330 °C contributes more in ACN production in FDO. ACN productivity at 380 °C was less than 360 °C invariant of FDO or SSO, which was due to an increase in the unselective oxidation to ACO, as NH3 was more preferentially oxidized to N2, and NH3 conversion approaches 100% above 360 °C (Fig S10a-b). However, when comparing ACN yield, the FDO performance was always higher than SSO in the 330 to 380 °C range (Fig. 5d). With the NH3 conversion discussed above, the ACN yield improvement is based on enhancement in C3H6 conversion, instead of selectivity towards ACN (Fig S10c-d). Under the conditions explored here, FDO has a pronounced effect at 330 °C, which we hypothesize is due to the relative lower rate of reoxidation versus reduction, at this relatively low temperature[45]. To help support this conclusion, we measured the activation energy in the temperature range used here, with results shown in Fig S11. The apparent activation energy was calculated based on formation rate of acrylonitrile. The apparent activation energy below 370 ºC is 195 kJ/mol. These results confirmed that at T < 370 ºC the reaction is reoxidation limited, where the reaction order in O2 is positive as indicated in Fig S8, and as this activation energy has been associated with reoxidation during propene selective oxidation over BMO-based catalysts in the literature [33,46–48]. Note that there was a dip in the ACN concentration profile at the onset of the first FDO cycle for the 310 °C experiment, following the initial rise, and this dip recurred in the ensuing cycles (Fig. 5a). This could indicate that surface oxygen was consumed first followed more slowly by oxygen from the catalyst bulk. 3.5 Effect of lattice oxygen The results when varying the O2 concentration during the FDO experiments show that regeneration with increased O2 dose led to improvement in catalytic performance. Prior literature indicates that lattice oxygen in the BMO catalyst may play a crucial role [31,43]. For example, using isotopically labeled 18O during propene selective oxidation showed that O in acrolein comes first from the catalyst [49,50]. Inspired by Brazdil and coworkers’ research on the redox activity of BMO-based catalysts [51], we quantitatively probed the impact of lattice oxygen in FDO by pretreating the industrial BMO catalyst with reducing cycles of C3H6 and NH3 without gaseous O2, shown schematically in Fig. 6a. The consumed lattice oxygen, evaluated by calculating the oxygen-containing products, grew with the number of reducing cycles, with 0 cycles meaning the catalyst was fresh, shown in Fig. 6b. After some number of cycles, the catalyst was tested under FDO experiment conditions, using the scheme described in Table 1 with a cycle period of 20 min and a 50% duty cycle. The ACN concentrations as a function of time, after 0, 1, 3 and 5 cycles of reduction are shown in Fig. 6c. There were different ACN amounts formed in the first FDO cycle, showing that different extents of reduction, and therefore available surface and lattice oxygen, affect yield. Also, as the number of reducing cycles increased, the ACN spike intensity decreased. With 1 reducing cycle, the degree of reduction appeared mild, the ACN spike intensity slightly decreased compared with that of the fresh sample, and after 4 cycles of FDO the performance was mostly recovered. With 3 reducing cycles, the ACN spike was initially absent. With 5 reducing cycles, the ACN trace not only did not show a spike, but instead there was a slow, monotonic rise observed in the first FDO phase. With these more deeply reduced samples, ACN production recovered partly with increasing FDO cycles, but after the few FDO cycles run in this experiment, the ACN production level still did not reach that of the fresh catalyst or the SSO level displayed in gray. However, recovery was observed to continue with each cycle, suggesting that a fully recovered catalyst can be attained, but requires more FDO cycles. A summary of the ACN production during the 1st FDO cycle with different reduction severity is shown in Fig. 6d. Our hypothesis is that ACN production decreases with extent of reduction due to loss in lattice oxygen, as there appears to be a correlation between ACN production and available oxygen, oxygen that was not removed by the reductants. Li’s work on selective oxidation of n-butane to maleic anhydride using FDO also showed a correlation between lattice oxygen and product maleic anhydride spike [31]. To amplify the impact of the ACN spike, we compare the catalytic performance in just the 1st cycle of FDO. The ACN yield and C3H6 conversion decreased with the decrease in the spike, while C2 and C1 product (acetaldehyde, CO, CO2, HCN) selectivities increased and C3 product (ACO and ACN) selectivities, especially toward ACO, decreased (Fig. 6e-f). The results show that depleting the catalyst’s lattice oxygen, which we correlate to the ACN spike, leads to decreased ACN formation activity, but increased deep propene oxidation, which contributes to less selectivity towards propene (amm)oxidation. These results match van Steen and colleagues’ findings in their research in propene partial oxidation [52,53], where they claimed that the nucleophilic oxygen species (oxygen from bulk of the lattice) was responsible for the partial oxidation products, whereas the electrophilic oxygen species (adsorbed oxygen from gaseous O2) was responsible for total oxidation products[54]. Therefore, we can reasonably surmise that the surface oxygen responsible for the enhanced ACN yield under FDO is not due to an adsorbed oxygen species but is rather a type of surface lattice oxygen. This conclusion stems, in part, from the fact that ACN is the same or better under FDO than SSO as noted previously. From these results, it appears that the ACN concentration profile can also reflect the oxidation state of the catalyst. We further investigated this by changing phase 2 gas composition, including just reductants or a combination of O2 and NH3 or C3H6, with results shown in Fig. 7, and detailed FDO schemes listed in Table 2. Phase 1 remained unchanged, and we used a cycle period of 20 min. In characterizing the fifth cycle, under the reductive environments (Fig. 7a), there were no spikes in ACN with the switch between phases, whereas under the oxidative environments, ACN spikes emerged (Fig. 7b). The lower the initial ACN concentration in the first cycle, i.e., the first 3 min spike (as indicated with the arrow), the more reduced the catalyst was, and the less lattice oxygen was available. From these results, it can be inferred that the reductive capability of gases follows this increasing order at 330 °C: NH3 < C3H6 < NH3 +C3H6. The results also show that mixing in NH3 or C3H6 with O2 in phase 2 leads to less ACN productivity in the following phase. 4 Conclusions A proof-of-concept study for the production of acrylonitrile via ammoxidation of propene using forced dynamic operation (FDO) was accomplished with an industrial multicomponent-promoted bismuth molybdate-based catalyst. An FDO scheme that leverages O2 regeneration of lattice oxygen was utilized. Effects of cycle period, duty cycle, O2 concentration during the regeneration phase, temperature and lattice oxygen were interrogated. At 330 °C, ACN yield using FDO surpasses SSO with a 50% duty cycle and cycle periods from 4 to 20 min, however, the ACN production is lower using FDO. Increasing the duty cycle from 50 to 90% enhances ACN production in FDO but it did not outperform SSO, and it also diminishes the ACN yield. ACN production and ACN yield can both be enhanced by increasing O2 concentration in the regeneration phase, at 0.6% O2 the ACN productivity and yield both exceeded those of SSO. At temperatures higher than 330 °C (360–380 °C) the ACN production and yield enhancement by FDO was not as pronounced because the rate of reoxidation was no longer as rate-limiting. The results show that the catalytic performance in forced dynamic operation can surpass that of the steady-state operation under certain conditions, i.e., when the catalyst is at some higher oxidation state or the active oxygen species is replenished, with that lattice oxygen availability appearing to play a crucial role in the FDO scheme employed. The use of this industrial catalyst, with an FDO approach, further demonstrates the potential of periodic operation in achieving better than SS product acrylonitrile yields, through leveraging the lattice O mobility of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Propene ammoxidation to acrylonitrile (ACN) over bismuth molybdate-based catalysts has been commercialized for more than 60 years. To meet forecasted growth, there is an opportunity for smaller-scale, decentralized ACN production. Forced dynamic operation (FDO), here referring to step changes in reactant inlet concentrations, has been used in low-volume production applications and has shown advantages in partial oxidation reactions. As a proof-of-concept study to evaluate FDO for acrylonitrile production, we applied periodic changes in inlet gas concentrations that varied between one phase containing all reactants and another that just contained O2, over an industrial bismuth molybdate-based catalyst. We varied the cycle period, duty cycle, and O2 concentration in the second phase and show that improved acrylonitrile yields can be obtained compared with those of steady-state operation under certain conditions. A correlation between lattice oxygen availability and FDO performance was observed.
coredata.dc:title: Propene ammoxidation over an industrial bismuth molybdate-based catalyst using forced dynamic operation
